# Discord Chat Analysis for ðŸ’»â”‚developers Channel

## 1. Summary:
The discussion primarily focused on animation and rendering optimizations in Hyperfy. Key technical topics included adding root bones to animations for proper IK functionality, with developers troubleshooting issues where feet were slipping during animations. Ashxn introduced occlusion culling implementation using pre-pass depth checking, allowing objects hidden behind walls/houses to be skipped during rendering, potentially offering significant performance improvements. The feature works by marking large objects as "occluders" with a simple checkbox. The chat also covered methods for extracting models from Cryptovoxels worlds and testing animations with different VRM/avatars. A GitHub repository for programmatically adding root bones to Mixamo animations was shared, along with a Vercel app hosting Hyperfy-compatible animations.

## 2. FAQ:
Q: Is a specific name needed for the root bone? (asked by carlosmu) A: "Root" but it doesn't matter much. The root bone is usually at origin 0,0,0 and doesn't move. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Would occlusion culling be set up manually or automatically? (asked by TheMattEmpire) A: You mark big objects as "occluders" and it automatically tests everything else to see if it's hidden behind those occluders. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is occlusion culling based on the asset or the collider? (asked by TheMattEmpire) A: It's based on the asset. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is there a way to pull the glb models from JSON of a CV world? (asked by ~/drdoge.eth) A: Unanswered
Q: Is there an easy way to get app object info similar to world.getPlayer/s? (asked by 0mka) A: Unanswered

# Discord Chat Analysis for ðŸ§Šâ”‚3d-design

## 1. Summary:
The chat primarily focused on technical aspects of 3D design for virtual environments. Key discussions included performance optimization techniques, specifically avoiding transparency in models and using alpha-cutout instead of alpha-blend for better performance on non-desktop platforms like mobile and VR. Community call highlights mentioned improved VR interactions, splat map experiments, housing kit development, and performance improvements including reduced memory usage and smaller Docker images. There was brief discussion about Auto Rig Pro's new AI integration, though details weren't elaborated. The conversation also touched on the closure of a game called Ember Sword, with some members suggesting it was a "rug pull" rather than simply running out of funding.
